SCENE Rome: the neighbourhood of Sardis: the neighbourhood of Philippi.
<LINE>Hence! home, you idle creatures get you home:</LINE>
<LINE>Is this a holiday? what! know you not,</LINE>
<LINE>Upon a labouring day without the sign</LINE>
<LINE>Of your profession? Speak, what trade art thou?</LINE>
<LINE>Where is thy leather apron and thy rule?</LINE>
<LINE>What dost thou with thy best apparel on?</LINE>
Truly, sir, in respect of a fine workman, I am but,
<LINE>But what trade art thou? answer me directly.</LINE>
<LINE>A trade, sir, that, I hope, I may use with a safe</LINE>
conscience; which is, indeed, sir, a mender of bad soles.
What trade, thou knave? thou naughty knave, what trade?
<LINE>Nay, I beseech you, sir, be not out with me: yet,</LINE>
<LINE>if you be out, sir, I can mend you.</LINE>
What meanest thou by that? mend me, thou saucy fellow!
<LINE>Truly, sir, all that I live by is with the awl: I</LINE>
<LINE>meddle with no tradesman's matters, nor women's</LINE>
matters, but with awl. I am, indeed, sir, a surgeon
<LINE>to old shoes; when they are in great danger, I</LINE>
<LINE>recover them. As proper men as ever trod upon</LINE>
<LINE>neat's leather have gone upon my handiwork.</LINE>
<LINE>But wherefore art not in thy shop today?</LINE>
<LINE>Why dost thou lead these men about the streets?</LINE>
<LINE>Truly, sir, to wear out their shoes, to get myself</LINE>
<LINE>into more work. But, indeed, sir, we make holiday,</LINE>
<LINE>to see Caesar and to rejoice in his triumph.</LINE>
<LINE>Wherefore rejoice? What conquest brings he home?</LINE>
<LINE>To grace in captive bonds his chariot-wheels?</LINE>
You blocks, you stones, you worse than senseless things!
<LINE>O you hard hearts, you cruel men of Rome,</LINE>
<LINE>Knew you not Pompey? Many a time and oft</LINE>
<LINE>Have you climb'd up to walls and battlements,</LINE>
<LINE>To towers and windows, yea, to chimney-tops,</LINE>
<LINE>Your infants in your arms, and there have sat</LINE>
<LINE>To see great Pompey pass the streets of Rome:</LINE>
<LINE>And when you saw his chariot but appear,</LINE>
<LINE>Have you not made an universal shout,</LINE>
<LINE>To hear the replication of your sounds</LINE>
<LINE>And do you now put on your best attire?</LINE>
<LINE>And do you now cull out a holiday?</LINE>
<LINE>And do you now strew flowers in his way</LINE>
That comes in triumph over Pompey's blood? Be gone!
<LINE>Run to your houses, fall upon your knees,</LINE>
<LINE>Pray to the gods to intermit the plague</LINE>
<LINE>That needs must light on this ingratitude.</LINE>
<LINE>Go, go, good countrymen, and, for this fault,</LINE>
<LINE>Assemble all the poor men of your sort;</LINE>
<LINE>Draw them to Tiber banks, and weep your tears</LINE>
<LINE>Into the channel, till the lowest stream</LINE>
<LINE>Do kiss the most exalted shores of all.</LINE>
<LINE>See whether their basest metal be not moved;</LINE>
<LINE>Go you down that way towards the Capitol;</LINE>
<LINE>This way will I disrobe the images,</LINE>
<LINE>If you do find them deck'd with ceremonies.</LINE>
<LINE>You know it is the feast of Lupercal.</LINE>
<LINE>It is no matter; let no images</LINE>
<LINE>Be hung with Caesar's trophies. I'll about,</LINE>
<LINE>And drive away the vulgar from the streets:</LINE>
<LINE>So do you too, where you perceive them thick.</LINE>
<LINE>These growing feathers pluck'd from Caesar's wing</LINE>
<LINE>Will make him fly an ordinary pitch,</LINE>
<LINE>Who else would soar above the view of men</LINE>
<LINE>And keep us all in servile fearfulness.</LINE>
Flourish. Enter CAESAR; ANTONY, for the course; CALPURNIA, PORTIA, DECIUS BRUTUS, CICERO, BRUTUS, CASSIUS, and CASCA; a great crowd following, among them a Soothsayer
<LINE>When he doth run his course. Antonius!</LINE>
<LINE>To touch Calpurnia; for our elders say,</LINE>
<LINE>The barren, touched in this holy chase,</LINE>
<LINE>When Caesar says 'do this,' it is perform'd.</LINE>
<LINE>Set on; and leave no ceremony out.</LINE>
<LINE>Bid every noise be still: peace yet again!</LINE>
<LINE>Who is it in the press that calls on me?</LINE>
<LINE>I hear a tongue, shriller than all the music,</LINE>
<LINE>Cry 'Caesar!' Speak; Caesar is turn'd to hear.</LINE>
<LINE>A soothsayer bids you beware the ides of March.</LINE>
<LINE>Set him before me; let me see his face.</LINE>
<LINE>Fellow, come from the throng; look upon Caesar.</LINE>
<LINE>What say'st thou to me now? speak once again.</LINE>
<LINE>He is a dreamer; let us leave him: pass.</LINE>
<STAGEDIR>Sennet. Exeunt all except BRUTUS and CASSIUS</STAGEDIR>
<LINE>Will you go see the order of the course?</LINE>
<LINE>I am not gamesome: I do lack some part</LINE>
<LINE>Of that quick spirit that is in Antony.</LINE>
<LINE>Let me not hinder, Cassius, your desires;</LINE>
<LINE>Brutus, I do observe you now of late:</LINE>
<LINE>I have not from your eyes that gentleness</LINE>
<LINE>And show of love as I was wont to have:</LINE>
<LINE>You bear too stubborn and too strange a hand</LINE>
<LINE>Be not deceived: if I have veil'd my look,</LINE>
<LINE>I turn the trouble of my countenance</LINE>
<LINE>Of late with passions of some difference,</LINE>
<LINE>Which give some soil perhaps to my behaviors;</LINE>
<LINE>But let not therefore my good friends be grieved--</LINE>
<LINE>Among which number, Cassius, be you one--</LINE>
<LINE>Than that poor Brutus, with himself at war,</LINE>
<LINE>Forgets the shows of love to other men.</LINE>
<LINE>Then, Brutus, I have much mistook your passion;</LINE>
<LINE>By means whereof this breast of mine hath buried</LINE>
<LINE>Tell me, good Brutus, can you see your face?</LINE>
<LINE>No, Cassius; for the eye sees not itself,</LINE>
<LINE>But by reflection, by some other things.</LINE>
<LINE>And it is very much lamented, Brutus,</LINE>
<LINE>That you have no such mirrors as will turn</LINE>
<LINE>That you might see your shadow. I have heard,</LINE>
<LINE>Where many of the best respect in Rome,</LINE>
<LINE>Have wish'd that noble Brutus had his eyes.</LINE>
<LINE>Into what dangers would you lead me, Cassius,</LINE>
<LINE>That you would have me seek into myself</LINE>
<LINE>For that which is not in me?</LINE>
<LINE>Therefore, good Brutus, be prepared to hear:</LINE>
<LINE>And since you know you cannot see yourself</LINE>
<LINE>So well as by reflection, I, your glass,</LINE>
<LINE>That of yourself which you yet know not of.</LINE>
<LINE>And be not jealous on me, gentle Brutus:</LINE>
<LINE>Were I a common laugher, or did use</LINE>
<LINE>To stale with ordinary oaths my love</LINE>
<LINE>To every new protester; if you know</LINE>
<LINE>That I do fawn on men and hug them hard</LINE>
<LINE>And after scandal them, or if you know</LINE>
<LINE>To all the rout, then hold me dangerous.</LINE>
<LINE>What means this shouting? I do fear, the people</LINE>
<LINE>Then must I think you would not have it so.</LINE>
<LINE>I would not, Cassius; yet I love him well.</LINE>
<LINE>But wherefore do you hold me here so long?</LINE>
<LINE>What is it that you would impart to me?</LINE>
<LINE>If it be aught toward the general good,</LINE>
<LINE>Set honour in one eye and death i' the other,</LINE>
<LINE>And I will look on both indifferently,</LINE>
<LINE>For let the gods so speed me as I love</LINE>
<LINE>The name of honour more than I fear death.</LINE>
<LINE>I know that virtue to be in you, Brutus,</LINE>
<LINE>As well as I do know your outward favour.</LINE>
<LINE>Well, honour is the subject of my story.</LINE>
<LINE>I cannot tell what you and other men</LINE>
<LINE>Think of this life; but, for my single self,</LINE>
<LINE>I had as lief not be as live to be</LINE>
<LINE>In awe of such a thing as I myself.</LINE>
<LINE>I was born free as Caesar; so were you:</LINE>
<LINE>We both have fed as well, and we can both</LINE>
<LINE>Endure the winter's cold as well as he:</LINE>
<LINE>For once, upon a raw and gusty day,</LINE>
<LINE>The troubled Tiber chafing with her shores,</LINE>
<LINE>Caesar said to me 'Darest thou, Cassius, now</LINE>
<LINE>Leap in with me into this angry flood,</LINE>
<LINE>And swim to yonder point?' Upon the word,</LINE>
<LINE>Accoutred as I was, I plunged in</LINE>
<LINE>And bade him follow; so indeed he did.</LINE>
<LINE>The torrent roar'd, and we did buffet it</LINE>
<LINE>And stemming it with hearts of controversy;</LINE>
<LINE>But ere we could arrive the point proposed,</LINE>
<LINE>Caesar cried 'Help me, Cassius, or I sink!'</LINE>
<LINE>Did from the flames of Troy upon his shoulder</LINE>
<LINE>The old Anchises bear, so from the waves of Tiber</LINE>
<LINE>Did I the tired Caesar. And this man</LINE>
<LINE>Is now become a god, and Cassius is</LINE>
<LINE>A wretched creature and must bend his body,</LINE>
<LINE>If Caesar carelessly but nod on him.</LINE>
<LINE>He had a fever when he was in Spain,</LINE>
<LINE>And when the fit was on him, I did mark</LINE>
<LINE>How he did shake: 'tis true, this god did shake;</LINE>
<LINE>His coward lips did from their colour fly,</LINE>
<LINE>And that same eye whose bend doth awe the world</LINE>
<LINE>Did lose his lustre: I did hear him groan:</LINE>
<LINE>Ay, and that tongue of his that bade the Romans</LINE>
<LINE>Mark him and write his speeches in their books,</LINE>
<LINE>Alas, it cried 'Give me some drink, Titinius,'</LINE>
<LINE>As a sick girl. Ye gods, it doth amaze me</LINE>
<LINE>A man of such a feeble temper should</LINE>
<LINE>So get the start of the majestic world</LINE>
<LINE>I do believe that these applauses are</LINE>
<LINE>For some new honours that are heap'd on Caesar.</LINE>
<LINE>Why, man, he doth bestride the narrow world</LINE>
<LINE>Like a Colossus, and we petty men</LINE>
<LINE>Walk under his huge legs and peep about</LINE>
<LINE>Men at some time are masters of their fates:</LINE>
<LINE>The fault, dear Brutus, is not in our stars,</LINE>
<LINE>But in ourselves, that we are underlings.</LINE>
Brutus and Caesar: what should be in that 'Caesar'?
<LINE>Why should that name be sounded more than yours?</LINE>
<LINE>Write them together, yours is as fair a name;</LINE>
<LINE>Sound them, it doth become the mouth as well;</LINE>
<LINE>Weigh them, it is as heavy; conjure with 'em,</LINE>
<LINE>Brutus will start a spirit as soon as Caesar.</LINE>
<LINE>Now, in the names of all the gods at once,</LINE>
<LINE>Upon what meat doth this our Caesar feed,</LINE>
<LINE>That he is grown so great? Age, thou art shamed!</LINE>
<LINE>Rome, thou hast lost the breed of noble bloods!</LINE>
<LINE>When went there by an age, since the great flood,</LINE>
<LINE>But it was famed with more than with one man?</LINE>
<LINE>When could they say till now, that talk'd of Rome,</LINE>
<LINE>That her wide walls encompass'd but one man?</LINE>
<LINE>Now is it Rome indeed and room enough,</LINE>
<LINE>When there is in it but one only man.</LINE>
<LINE>O, you and I have heard our fathers say,</LINE>
<LINE>There was a Brutus once that would have brook'd</LINE>
<LINE>The eternal devil to keep his state in Rome</LINE>
<LINE>That you do love me, I am nothing jealous;</LINE>
<LINE>What you would work me to, I have some aim:</LINE>
<LINE>How I have thought of this and of these times,</LINE>
<LINE>I shall recount hereafter; for this present,</LINE>
<LINE>I would not, so with love I might entreat you,</LINE>
<LINE>Be any further moved. What you have said</LINE>
<LINE>I will consider; what you have to say</LINE>
<LINE>I will with patience hear, and find a time</LINE>
<LINE>Both meet to hear and answer such high things.</LINE>
<LINE>Till then, my noble friend, chew upon this:</LINE>
<LINE>Than to repute himself a son of Rome</LINE>
<LINE>Under these hard conditions as this time</LINE>
<LINE>I am glad that my weak words</LINE>
Have struck but thus much show of fire from Brutus.
<LINE>The games are done and Caesar is returning.</LINE>
<LINE>As they pass by, pluck Casca by the sleeve;</LINE>
<LINE>And he will, after his sour fashion, tell you</LINE>
<LINE>I will do so. But, look you, Cassius,</LINE>
<LINE>The angry spot doth glow on Caesar's brow,</LINE>
<LINE>And all the rest look like a chidden train:</LINE>
<LINE>Looks with such ferret and such fiery eyes</LINE>
<LINE>As we have seen him in the Capitol,</LINE>
<LINE>Being cross'd in conference by some senators.</LINE>
<LINE>Casca will tell us what the matter is.</LINE>
<LINE>Let me have men about me that are fat;</LINE>
<LINE>Sleek-headed men and such as sleep o' nights:</LINE>
<LINE>Yond Cassius has a lean and hungry look;</LINE>
<LINE>He thinks too much: such men are dangerous.</LINE>
<LINE>Fear him not, Caesar; he's not dangerous;</LINE>
<LINE>He is a noble Roman and well given.</LINE>
<LINE>Would he were fatter! But I fear him not:</LINE>
<LINE>Yet if my name were liable to fear,</LINE>
<LINE>I do not know the man I should avoid</LINE>
<LINE>So soon as that spare Cassius. He reads much;</LINE>
<LINE>He is a great observer and he looks</LINE>
<LINE>Quite through the deeds of men: he loves no plays,</LINE>
<LINE>As thou dost, Antony; he hears no music;</LINE>
<LINE>Seldom he smiles, and smiles in such a sort</LINE>
<LINE>As if he mock'd himself and scorn'd his spirit</LINE>
<LINE>That could be moved to smile at any thing.</LINE>
<LINE>Such men as he be never at heart's ease</LINE>
<LINE>Whiles they behold a greater than themselves,</LINE>
<LINE>I rather tell thee what is to be fear'd</LINE>
<LINE>Than what I fear; for always I am Caesar.</LINE>
<LINE>Come on my right hand, for this ear is deaf,</LINE>
<LINE>And tell me truly what thou think'st of him.</LINE>
<STAGEDIR>Sennet. Exeunt CAESAR and all his Train, but CASCA</STAGEDIR>
You pull'd me by the cloak; would you speak with me?
<LINE>Ay, Casca; tell us what hath chanced to-day,</LINE>
<LINE>Why, you were with him, were you not?</LINE>
<LINE>I should not then ask Casca what had chanced.</LINE>
<LINE>Why, there was a crown offered him: and being</LINE>
offered him, he put it by with the back of his hand,
<LINE>thus; and then the people fell a-shouting.</LINE>
<LINE>They shouted thrice: what was the last cry for?</LINE>
<LINE>Ay, marry, was't, and he put it by thrice, every</LINE>

<LINE>Tell us the manner of it, gentle Casca.</LINE>
<LINE>I can as well be hanged as tell the manner of it:</LINE>
<LINE>it was mere foolery; I did not mark it. I saw Mark</LINE>
<LINE>Antony offer him a crown;--yet 'twas not a crown</LINE>
neither, 'twas one of these coronets;--and, as I told
<LINE>you, he put it by once: but, for all that, to my</LINE>
<LINE>thinking, he would fain have had it. Then he</LINE>
<LINE>offered it to him again; then he put it by again:</LINE>
<LINE>but, to my thinking, he was very loath to lay his</LINE>
<LINE>fingers off it. And then he offered it the third</LINE>
<LINE>time; he put it the third time by: and still as he</LINE>
refused it, the rabblement hooted and clapped their
<LINE>chapped hands and threw up their sweaty night-caps</LINE>
<LINE>and uttered such a deal of stinking breath because</LINE>
<LINE>Caesar refused the crown that it had almost choked</LINE>
<LINE>Caesar; for he swounded and fell down at it: and</LINE>
<LINE>for mine own part, I durst not laugh, for fear of</LINE>
<LINE>opening my lips and receiving the bad air.</LINE>
<LINE>But, soft, I pray you: what, did Caesar swound?</LINE>
<LINE>He fell down in the market-place, and foamed at</LINE>
<LINE>'Tis very like: he hath the failing sickness.</LINE>
<LINE>No, Caesar hath it not; but you and I,</LINE>
<LINE>And honest Casca, we have the falling sickness.</LINE>
<LINE>I know not what you mean by that; but, I am sure,</LINE>
<LINE>Caesar fell down. If the tag-rag people did not</LINE>
<LINE>clap him and hiss him, according as he pleased and</LINE>
<LINE>displeased them, as they use to do the players in</LINE>
<LINE>the theatre, I am no true man.</LINE>
<LINE>What said he when he came unto himself?</LINE>
<LINE>Marry, before he fell down, when he perceived the</LINE>
<LINE>common herd was glad he refused the crown, he</LINE>
<LINE>plucked me ope his doublet and offered them his</LINE>
<LINE>throat to cut. An I had been a man of any</LINE>
occupation, if I would not have taken him at a word,
I would I might go to hell among the rogues. And so
<LINE>he fell. When he came to himself again, he said,</LINE>
<LINE>If he had done or said any thing amiss, he desired</LINE>
their worships to think it was his infirmity. Three
<LINE>or four wenches, where I stood, cried 'Alas, good</LINE>
<LINE>soul!' and forgave him with all their hearts: but</LINE>
<LINE>there's no heed to be taken of them; if Caesar had</LINE>
stabbed their mothers, they would have done no less.
<LINE>And after that, he came, thus sad, away?</LINE>
<LINE>Nay, an I tell you that, Ill ne'er look you i' the</LINE>
face again: but those that understood him smiled at
one another and shook their heads; but, for mine own
<LINE>part, it was Greek to me. I could tell you more</LINE>
<LINE>news too: Marullus and Flavius, for pulling scarfs</LINE>
<LINE>off Caesar's images, are put to silence. Fare you</LINE>
<LINE>well. There was more foolery yet, if I could</LINE>
<LINE>Will you sup with me to-night, Casca?</LINE>
Ay, if I be alive and your mind hold and your dinner
<LINE>What a blunt fellow is this grown to be!</LINE>
<LINE>He was quick mettle when he went to school.</LINE>
<LINE>However he puts on this tardy form.</LINE>
<LINE>This rudeness is a sauce to his good wit,</LINE>
<LINE>Which gives men stomach to digest his words</LINE>
<LINE>And so it is. For this time I will leave you:</LINE>
<LINE>To-morrow, if you please to speak with me,</LINE>
<LINE>I will come home to you; or, if you will,</LINE>
<LINE>Come home to me, and I will wait for you.</LINE>
<LINE>I will do so: till then, think of the world.</LINE>
<LINE>Well, Brutus, thou art noble; yet, I see,</LINE>
<LINE>From that it is disposed: therefore it is meet</LINE>
<LINE>That noble minds keep ever with their likes;</LINE>
<LINE>For who so firm that cannot be seduced?</LINE>

<LINE>And after this let Caesar seat him sure;</LINE>
<LINE>For we will shake him, or worse days endure.</LINE>
Thunder and lightning. Enter from opposite sides, CASCA, with his sword drawn, and CICERO
<LINE>Good even, Casca: brought you Caesar home?</LINE>
<LINE>Why are you breathless? and why stare you so?</LINE>
<LINE>Are not you moved, when all the sway of earth</LINE>
<LINE>Shakes like a thing unfirm? O Cicero,</LINE>
<LINE>I have seen tempests, when the scolding winds</LINE>
<LINE>Have rived the knotty oaks, and I have seen</LINE>
<LINE>The ambitious ocean swell and rage and foam,</LINE>
<LINE>To be exalted with the threatening clouds:</LINE>
<LINE>But never till to-night, never till now,</LINE>
<LINE>Did I go through a tempest dropping fire.</LINE>
<LINE>Either there is a civil strife in heaven,</LINE>
<LINE>Or else the world, too saucy with the gods,</LINE>
<LINE>Why, saw you any thing more wonderful?</LINE>
<LINE>A common slave--you know him well by sight--</LINE>
<LINE>Held up his left hand, which did flame and burn</LINE>
<LINE>Like twenty torches join'd, and yet his hand,</LINE>
<LINE>Besides--I ha' not since put up my sword--</LINE>

<LINE>And yesterday the bird of night did sit</LINE>

<LINE>Good night then, Casca: this disturbed sky</LINE>
<LINE>Your ear is good. Cassius, what night is this!</LINE>
<LINE>A very pleasing night to honest men.</LINE>
<LINE>Who ever knew the heavens menace so?</LINE>
<LINE>Those that have known the earth so full of faults.</LINE>
<LINE>For my part, I have walk'd about the streets,</LINE>
<LINE>And, thus unbraced, Casca, as you see,</LINE>

<LINE>When the most mighty gods by tokens send</LINE>
<LINE>You are dull, Casca, and those sparks of life</LINE>
<LINE>That should be in a Roman you do want,</LINE>
<LINE>Or else you use not. You look pale and gaze</LINE>
<LINE>And put on fear and cast yourself in wonder,</LINE>
<LINE>To see the strange impatience of the heavens:</LINE>
<LINE>But if you would consider the true cause</LINE>
<LINE>Why all these fires, why all these gliding ghosts,</LINE>
<LINE>Why birds and beasts from quality and kind,</LINE>
<LINE>Why old men fool and children calculate,</LINE>
<LINE>Why all these things change from their ordinance</LINE>
<LINE>That heaven hath infused them with these spirits,</LINE>
<LINE>To make them instruments of fear and warning</LINE>
<LINE>Now could I, Casca, name to thee a man</LINE>
<LINE>That thunders, lightens, opens graves, and roars</LINE>
<LINE>As doth the lion in the Capitol,</LINE>
<LINE>A man no mightier than thyself or me</LINE>
<LINE>And fearful, as these strange eruptions are.</LINE>
<LINE>'Tis Caesar that you mean; is it not, Cassius?</LINE>
<LINE>Let it be who it is: for Romans now</LINE>
<LINE>Have thews and limbs like to their ancestors;</LINE>
<LINE>But, woe the while! our fathers' minds are dead,</LINE>
<LINE>And we are govern'd with our mothers' spirits;</LINE>
<LINE>Our yoke and sufferance show us womanish.</LINE>
<LINE>Mean to establish Caesar as a king;</LINE>
<LINE>And he shall wear his crown by sea and land,</LINE>
<LINE>In every place, save here in Italy.</LINE>
<LINE>I know where I will wear this dagger then;</LINE>
<LINE>Therein, ye gods, you make the weak most strong;</LINE>
<LINE>Therein, ye gods, you tyrants do defeat:</LINE>
<LINE>Nor stony tower, nor walls of beaten brass,</LINE>
<LINE>Nor airless dungeon, nor strong links of iron,</LINE>

<LINE>But life, being weary of these worldly bars,</LINE>
<LINE>If I know this, know all the world besides,</LINE>

<LINE>So every bondman in his own hand bears</LINE>
<LINE>And why should Caesar be a tyrant then?</LINE>
<LINE>Poor man! I know he would not be a wolf,</LINE>
<LINE>But that he sees the Romans are but sheep:</LINE>

<LINE>Here is the will, and under Caesar's seal.</LINE>
<LINE>Most noble Caesar! We'll revenge his death.</LINE>
<LINE>Moreover, he hath left you all his walks,</LINE>
<LINE>On this side Tiber; he hath left them you,</LINE>
<LINE>And to your heirs for ever, common pleasures,</LINE>
<LINE>Here was a Caesar! when comes such another?</LINE>
<LINE>We'll burn his body in the holy place,</LINE>
<LINE>And with the brands fire the traitors' houses.</LINE>
<LINE>Now let it work. Mischief, thou art afoot,</LINE>
<LINE>Sir, Octavius is already come to Rome.</LINE>
<LINE>He and Lepidus are at Caesar's house.</LINE>
<LINE>And thither will I straight to visit him:</LINE>
<LINE>He comes upon a wish. Fortune is merry,</LINE>
<LINE>And in this mood will give us any thing.</LINE>
<LINE>I heard him say, Brutus and Cassius</LINE>
<LINE>Are rid like madmen through the gates of Rome.</LINE>
<LINE>Belike they had some notice of the people,</LINE>
<LINE>How I had moved them. Bring me to Octavius.</LINE>
<LINE>I dreamt to-night that I did feast with Caesar,</LINE>
<LINE>I have no will to wander forth of doors,</LINE>
<LINE>Are you a married man or a bachelor?</LINE>
<LINE>What is my name? Whither am I going? Where do I</LINE>
<LINE>dwell? Am I a married man or a bachelor? Then, to</LINE>
<LINE>answer every man directly and briefly, wisely and</LINE>
<LINE>truly: wisely I say, I am a bachelor.</LINE>
That's as much as to say, they are fools that marry:
you'll bear me a bang for that, I fear. Proceed; directly.
<LINE>Directly, I am going to Caesar's funeral.</LINE>
<LINE>Tear him to pieces; he's a conspirator.</LINE>
<LINE>I am Cinna the poet, I am Cinna the poet.</LINE>
Tear him for his bad verses, tear him for his bad verses.
<LINE>It is no matter, his name's Cinna; pluck but his</LINE>
<LINE>name out of his heart, and turn him going.</LINE>
<LINE>Tear him, tear him! Come, brands ho! fire-brands:</LINE>
<LINE>to Brutus', to Cassius'; burn all: some to Decius'</LINE>
house, and some to Casca's; some to Ligarius': away, go!
<STAGEDIR>ANTONY, OCTAVIUS, and LEPIDUS, seated at a table</STAGEDIR>
These many, then, shall die; their names are prick'd.
<LINE>Your brother too must die; consent you, Lepidus?</LINE>
<LINE>Who is your sister's son, Mark Antony.</LINE>
<LINE>He shall not live; look, with a spot I damn him.</LINE>
<LINE>But, Lepidus, go you to Caesar's house;</LINE>
<LINE>Fetch the will hither, and we shall determine</LINE>
<LINE>How to cut off some charge in legacies.</LINE>
<LINE>Meet to be sent on errands: is it fit,</LINE>
<LINE>The three-fold world divided, he should stand</LINE>
<LINE>One of the three to share it?</LINE>
<LINE>And took his voice who should be prick'd to die,</LINE>
<LINE>Octavius, I have seen more days than you:</LINE>
<LINE>And though we lay these honours on this man,</LINE>
<LINE>To ease ourselves of divers slanderous loads,</LINE>
<LINE>He shall but bear them as the ass bears gold,</LINE>
<LINE>To groan and sweat under the business,</LINE>
<LINE>Either led or driven, as we point the way;</LINE>
<LINE>And having brought our treasure where we will,</LINE>
<LINE>Then take we down his load, and turn him off,</LINE>
<LINE>Like to the empty ass, to shake his ears,</LINE>
<LINE>But he's a tried and valiant soldier.</LINE>
<LINE>So is my horse, Octavius; and for that</LINE>
<LINE>I do appoint him store of provender:</LINE>
<LINE>It is a creature that I teach to fight,</LINE>
<LINE>To wind, to stop, to run directly on,</LINE>
<LINE>His corporal motion govern'd by my spirit.</LINE>
<LINE>And, in some taste, is Lepidus but so;</LINE>
<LINE>He must be taught and train'd and bid go forth;</LINE>
<LINE>Which, out of use and staled by other men,</LINE>
<LINE>Begin his fashion: do not talk of him,</LINE>
<LINE>But as a property. And now, Octavius,</LINE>
<LINE>Are levying powers: we must straight make head:</LINE>
<LINE>Our best friends made, our means stretch'd</LINE>
<LINE>And let us presently go sit in council,</LINE>
<LINE>How covert matters may be best disclosed,</LINE>
<LINE>Let us do so: for we are at the stake,</LINE>
<LINE>And some that smile have in their hearts, I fear,</LINE>
<TITLE>SCENE II. Camp near Sardis. Before BRUTUS's tent.</TITLE>
Drum. Enter BRUTUS, LUCILIUS, LUCIUS, and Soldiers; TITINIUS and PINDARUS meeting them
<LINE>He is at hand; and Pindarus is come</LINE>
<LINE>To do you salutation from his master.</LINE>
<LINE>He greets me well. Your master, Pindarus,</LINE>
<LINE>In his own change, or by ill officers,</LINE>
<LINE>Hath given me some worthy cause to wish</LINE>
<LINE>Things done, undone: but, if he be at hand,</LINE>
<LINE>But that my noble master will appear</LINE>
<LINE>Such as he is, full of regard and honour.</LINE>
<LINE>He is not doubted. A word, Lucilius;</LINE>
<LINE>How he received you, let me be resolved.</LINE>
<LINE>Nor with such free and friendly conference,</LINE>
<LINE>A hot friend cooling: ever note, Lucilius,</LINE>
<LINE>When love begins to sicken and decay,</LINE>
<LINE>There are no tricks in plain and simple faith;</LINE>
<LINE>But hollow men, like horses hot at hand,</LINE>
<LINE>Make gallant show and promise of their mettle;</LINE>
<LINE>But when they should endure the bloody spur,</LINE>
<LINE>They fall their crests, and, like deceitful jades,</LINE>
<LINE>Sink in the trial. Comes his army on?</LINE>
<LINE>They mean this night in Sardis to be quarter'd;</LINE>
<LINE>The greater part, the horse in general,</LINE>
<LINE>Most noble brother, you have done me wrong.</LINE>
<LINE>Judge me, you gods! wrong I mine enemies?</LINE>
<LINE>And, if not so, how should I wrong a brother?</LINE>
<LINE>Brutus, this sober form of yours hides wrongs;</LINE>
<LINE>Speak your griefs softly: I do know you well.</LINE>
<LINE>Before the eyes of both our armies here,</LINE>
<LINE>Which should perceive nothing but love from us,</LINE>
<LINE>Let us not wrangle: bid them move away;</LINE>
<LINE>Then in my tent, Cassius, enlarge your griefs,</LINE>
<LINE>Bid our commanders lead their charges off</LINE>
<LINE>Lucilius, do you the like; and let no man</LINE>
<LINE>Come to our tent till we have done our conference.</LINE>
<LINE>Let Lucius and Titinius guard our door.</LINE>
<LINE>That you have wrong'd me doth appear in this:</LINE>
<LINE>You have condemn'd and noted Lucius Pella</LINE>
<LINE>For taking bribes here of the Sardians;</LINE>
<LINE>Wherein my letters, praying on his side,</LINE>
<LINE>Because I knew the man, were slighted off.</LINE>
<LINE>You wronged yourself to write in such a case.</LINE>
<LINE>In such a time as this it is not meet</LINE>
<LINE>That every nice offence should bear his comment.</LINE>
<LINE>Let me tell you, Cassius, you yourself</LINE>
<LINE>Are much condemn'd to have an itching palm;</LINE>
<LINE>To sell and mart your offices for gold</LINE>
<LINE>You know that you are Brutus that speak this,</LINE>
<LINE>Or, by the gods, this speech were else your last.</LINE>
<LINE>The name of Cassius honours this corruption,</LINE>
<LINE>And chastisement doth therefore hide his head.</LINE>
<LINE>Remember March, the ides of March remember:</LINE>
<LINE>Did not great Julius bleed for justice' sake?</LINE>
<LINE>What villain touch'd his body, that did stab,</LINE>
<LINE>And not for justice? What, shall one of us</LINE>
<LINE>That struck the foremost man of all this world</LINE>
<LINE>But for supporting robbers, shall we now</LINE>
<LINE>And sell the mighty space of our large honours</LINE>
<LINE>For so much trash as may be grasped thus?</LINE>
<LINE>I had rather be a dog, and bay the moon,</LINE>
<LINE>I'll not endure it: you forget yourself,</LINE>
<LINE>To hedge me in; I am a soldier, I,</LINE>
<LINE>Urge me no more, I shall forget myself;</LINE>
<LINE>Have mind upon your health, tempt me no further.</LINE>
<LINE>Must I give way and room to your rash choler?</LINE>
<LINE>Shall I be frighted when a madman stares?</LINE>
<LINE>O ye gods, ye gods! must I endure all this?</LINE>
All this! ay, more: fret till your proud heart break;
<LINE>Go show your slaves how choleric you are,</LINE>
<LINE>And make your bondmen tremble. Must I budge?</LINE>
<LINE>Must I observe you? must I stand and crouch</LINE>
<LINE>Under your testy humour? By the gods</LINE>
<LINE>You shall digest the venom of your spleen,</LINE>
<LINE>Though it do split you; for, from this day forth,</LINE>
<LINE>I'll use you for my mirth, yea, for my laughter,</LINE>
<LINE>You say you are a better soldier:</LINE>
<LINE>Let it appear so; make your vaunting true,</LINE>
<LINE>And it shall please me well: for mine own part,</LINE>
<LINE>I shall be glad to learn of noble men.</LINE>
<LINE>You wrong me every way; you wrong me, Brutus;</LINE>
<LINE>I said, an elder soldier, not a better:</LINE>
When Caesar lived, he durst not thus have moved me.
<LINE>Peace, peace! you durst not so have tempted him.</LINE>
<LINE>Do not presume too much upon my love;</LINE>
<LINE>I may do that I shall be sorry for.</LINE>
<LINE>You have done that you should be sorry for.</LINE>
<LINE>There is no terror, Cassius, in your threats,</LINE>
<LINE>For I am arm'd so strong in honesty</LINE>
<LINE>That they pass by me as the idle wind,</LINE>
<LINE>Which I respect not. I did send to you</LINE>
<LINE>For certain sums of gold, which you denied me:</LINE>
<LINE>For I can raise no money by vile means:</LINE>
<LINE>By heaven, I had rather coin my heart,</LINE>
<LINE>And drop my blood for drachmas, than to wring</LINE>
<LINE>From the hard hands of peasants their vile trash</LINE>
<LINE>To you for gold to pay my legions,</LINE>
<LINE>Which you denied me: was that done like Cassius?</LINE>
<LINE>Should I have answer'd Caius Cassius so?</LINE>
<LINE>To lock such rascal counters from his friends,</LINE>
<LINE>Be ready, gods, with all your thunderbolts;</LINE>
<LINE>I did not: he was but a fool that brought</LINE>
<LINE>My answer back. Brutus hath rived my heart:</LINE>
<LINE>A friend should bear his friend's infirmities,</LINE>
<LINE>But Brutus makes mine greater than they are.</LINE>
<LINE>I do not, till you practise them on me.</LINE>
<LINE>A friendly eye could never see such faults.</LINE>
<LINE>A flatterer's would not, though they do appear</LINE>
<LINE>For Cassius is aweary of the world;</LINE>
<LINE>Hated by one he loves; braved by his brother;</LINE>
<LINE>Cheque'd like a bondman; all his faults observed,</LINE>
<LINE>Set in a note-book, learn'd, and conn'd by rote,</LINE>
<LINE>To cast into my teeth. O, I could weep</LINE>
<LINE>My spirit from mine eyes! There is my dagger,</LINE>
<LINE>And here my naked breast; within, a heart</LINE>
<LINE>Dearer than Plutus' mine, richer than gold:</LINE>
<LINE>If that thou be'st a Roman, take it forth;</LINE>
<LINE>I, that denied thee gold, will give my heart:</LINE>
<LINE>Strike, as thou didst at Caesar; for, I know,</LINE>
When thou didst hate him worst, thou lovedst him better
<LINE>Be angry when you will, it shall have scope;</LINE>
<LINE>Do what you will, dishonour shall be humour.</LINE>
<LINE>O Cassius, you are yoked with a lamb</LINE>
<LINE>That carries anger as the flint bears fire;</LINE>
<LINE>Who, much enforced, shows a hasty spark,</LINE>
<LINE>To be but mirth and laughter to his Brutus,</LINE>
<LINE>When grief, and blood ill-temper'd, vexeth him?</LINE>
<LINE>When I spoke that, I was ill-temper'd too.</LINE>
<LINE>Do you confess so much? Give me your hand.</LINE>
<LINE>Have not you love enough to bear with me,</LINE>
<LINE>When that rash humour which my mother gave me</LINE>
<LINE>When you are over-earnest with your Brutus,</LINE>
<LINE>He'll think your mother chides, and leave you so.</LINE>
Let me go in to see the generals;
<LINE>There is some grudge between 'em, 'tis not meet</LINE>
You shall not come to them.
Nothing but death shall stay me.
Enter Poet, followed by LUCILIUS, TITINIUS, and LUCIUS
<LINE>For shame, you generals! what do you mean?</LINE>
<LINE>Love, and be friends, as two such men should be;</LINE>
<LINE>For I have seen more years, I'm sure, than ye.</LINE>
<LINE>Ha, ha! how vilely doth this cynic rhyme!</LINE>
<LINE>Get you hence, sirrah; saucy fellow, hence!</LINE>
<LINE>I'll know his humour, when he knows his time:</LINE>
<LINE>What should the wars do with these jigging fools?</LINE>
<LINE>And come yourselves, and bring Messala with you</LINE>
<LINE>I did not think you could have been so angry.</LINE>
<LINE>O Cassius, I am sick of many griefs.</LINE>
<LINE>Of your philosophy you make no use,</LINE>
<LINE>If you give place to accidental evils.</LINE>
<LINE>No man bears sorrow better. Portia is dead.</LINE>
<LINE>How 'scaped I killing when I cross'd you so?</LINE>
<LINE>And grief that young Octavius with Mark Antony</LINE>
Have made themselves so strong:--for with her death
<LINE>That tidings came;--with this she fell distract,</LINE>
<LINE>Speak no more of her. Give me a bowl of wine.</LINE>
<LINE>In this I bury all unkindness, Cassius.</LINE>
<LINE>My heart is thirsty for that noble pledge.</LINE>
<LINE>Fill, Lucius, till the wine o'erswell the cup;</LINE>
<LINE>I cannot drink too much of Brutus' love.</LINE>
<LINE>Now sit we close about this taper here,</LINE>
<LINE>Come down upon us with a mighty power,</LINE>
<LINE>Myself have letters of the selfsame tenor.</LINE>
<LINE>That by proscription and bills of outlawry,</LINE>
<LINE>Have put to death an hundred senators.</LINE>
<LINE>Therein our letters do not well agree;</LINE>
<LINE>Mine speak of seventy senators that died</LINE>
<LINE>Had you your letters from your wife, my lord?</LINE>
<LINE>Nor nothing in your letters writ of her?</LINE>
<LINE>Why ask you? hear you aught of her in yours?</LINE>
<LINE>Now, as you are a Roman, tell me true.</LINE>
<LINE>Then like a Roman bear the truth I tell:</LINE>
<LINE>For certain she is dead, and by strange manner.</LINE>
<LINE>Why, farewell, Portia. We must die, Messala:</LINE>
<LINE>With meditating that she must die once,</LINE>
<LINE>I have the patience to endure it now.</LINE>
<LINE>Even so great men great losses should endure.</LINE>
<LINE>I have as much of this in art as you,</LINE>
<LINE>But yet my nature could not bear it so.</LINE>
<LINE>Well, to our work alive. What do you think</LINE>
<LINE>'Tis better that the enemy seek us:</LINE>
<LINE>So shall he waste his means, weary his soldiers,</LINE>
<LINE>Doing himself offence; whilst we, lying still,</LINE>
<LINE>Are full of rest, defense, and nimbleness.</LINE>
<LINE>Good reasons must, of force, give place to better.</LINE>
<LINE>Do stand but in a forced affection;</LINE>
<LINE>By them shall make a fuller number up,</LINE>
<LINE>From which advantage shall we cut him off,</LINE>
<LINE>If at Philippi we do face him there,</LINE>
<LINE>Under your pardon. You must note beside,</LINE>
<LINE>That we have tried the utmost of our friends,</LINE>
<LINE>Our legions are brim-full, our cause is ripe:</LINE>
<LINE>We, at the height, are ready to decline.</LINE>
<LINE>There is a tide in the affairs of men,</LINE>
<LINE>Which, taken at the flood, leads on to fortune;</LINE>
<LINE>Omitted, all the voyage of their life</LINE>
<LINE>Is bound in shallows and in miseries.</LINE>
<LINE>On such a full sea are we now afloat;</LINE>
<LINE>And we must take the current when it serves,</LINE>
<LINE>We'll along ourselves, and meet them at Philippi.</LINE>
<LINE>The deep of night is crept upon our talk,</LINE>
<LINE>Which we will niggard with a little rest.</LINE>
<LINE>Early to-morrow will we rise, and hence.</LINE>
<LINE>This was an ill beginning of the night:</LINE>
<LINE>Give me the gown. Where is thy instrument?</LINE>
Poor knave, I blame thee not; thou art o'er-watch'd.
<LINE>Call Claudius and some other of my men:</LINE>
<LINE>I'll have them sleep on cushions in my tent.</LINE>
<LINE>I pray you, sirs, lie in my tent and sleep;</LINE>
<LINE>It may be I shall raise you by and by</LINE>
So please you, we will stand and watch your pleasure.
<LINE>I will not have it so: lie down, good sirs;</LINE>
<LINE>It may be I shall otherwise bethink me.</LINE>
<LINE>Look, Lucius, here's the book I sought for so;</LINE>
<LINE>I put it in the pocket of my gown.</LINE>
<LINE>I was sure your lordship did not give it me.</LINE>
<LINE>Bear with me, good boy, I am much forgetful.</LINE>
<LINE>Canst thou hold up thy heavy eyes awhile,</LINE>
<LINE>And touch thy instrument a strain or two?</LINE>
<LINE>I trouble thee too much, but thou art willing.</LINE>
<LINE>I should not urge thy duty past thy might;</LINE>
<LINE>I know young bloods look for a time of rest.</LINE>
<LINE>It was well done; and thou shalt sleep again;</LINE>
<LINE>I will not hold thee long: if I do live,</LINE>
<LINE>This is a sleepy tune. O murderous slumber,</LINE>
<LINE>Lay'st thou thy leaden mace upon my boy,</LINE>
<LINE>That plays thee music? Gentle knave, good night;</LINE>
<LINE>I will not do thee so much wrong to wake thee:</LINE>
<LINE>If thou dost nod, thou break'st thy instrument;</LINE>
<LINE>I'll take it from thee; and, good boy, good night.</LINE>
Let me see, let me see; is not the leaf turn'd down
<LINE>Where I left reading? Here it is, I think.</LINE>
<LINE>How ill this taper burns! Ha! who comes here?</LINE>
<LINE>I think it is the weakness of mine eyes</LINE>
<LINE>It comes upon me. Art thou any thing?</LINE>
<LINE>Art thou some god, some angel, or some devil,</LINE>
<LINE>That makest my blood cold and my hair to stare?</LINE>
<LINE>To tell thee thou shalt see me at Philippi.</LINE>
<LINE>Well; then I shall see thee again?</LINE>
<LINE>Why, I will see thee at Philippi, then.</LINE>
<LINE>Now I have taken heart thou vanishest:</LINE>
<LINE>Ill spirit, I would hold more talk with thee.</LINE>
Boy, Lucius! Varro! Claudius! Sirs, awake! Claudius!
<LINE>He thinks he still is at his instrument.</LINE>
Didst thou dream, Lucius, that thou so criedst out?
<LINE>My lord, I do not know that I did cry.</LINE>
<LINE>Yes, that thou didst: didst thou see any thing?</LINE>
<LINE>Why did you so cry out, sirs, in your sleep?</LINE>
<LINE>Go and commend me to my brother Cassius;</LINE>
<LINE>Bid him set on his powers betimes before,</LINE>
<LINE>You said the enemy would not come down,</LINE>
<LINE>But keep the hills and upper regions;</LINE>
<LINE>It proves not so: their battles are at hand;</LINE>
<LINE>They mean to warn us at Philippi here,</LINE>
<LINE>Answering before we do demand of them.</LINE>
<LINE>Tut, I am in their bosoms, and I know</LINE>
<LINE>Wherefore they do it: they could be content</LINE>
<LINE>To visit other places; and come down</LINE>
<LINE>With fearful bravery, thinking by this face</LINE>
<LINE>To fasten in our thoughts that they have courage;</LINE>
<LINE>The enemy comes on in gallant show;</LINE>
<LINE>Their bloody sign of battle is hung out,</LINE>
<LINE>Upon the left hand of the even field.</LINE>
<LINE>Upon the right hand I; keep thou the left.</LINE>
<LINE>Why do you cross me in this exigent?</LINE>
<LINE>I do not cross you; but I will do so.</LINE>
Drum. Enter BRUTUS, CASSIUS, and their Army; LUCILIUS, TITINIUS, MESSALA, and others
<LINE>Stand fast, Titinius: we must out and talk.</LINE>
<LINE>Mark Antony, shall we give sign of battle?</LINE>
<LINE>No, Caesar, we will answer on their charge.</LINE>
<LINE>Make forth; the generals would have some words.</LINE>
<LINE>Words before blows: is it so, countrymen?</LINE>
<LINE>Not that we love words better, as you do.</LINE>
<LINE>Good words are better than bad strokes, Octavius.</LINE>
<LINE>In your bad strokes, Brutus, you give good words:</LINE>
<LINE>Witness the hole you made in Caesar's heart,</LINE>
<LINE>The posture of your blows are yet unknown;</LINE>
<LINE>But for your words, they rob the Hybla bees,</LINE>
<LINE>For you have stol'n their buzzing, Antony,</LINE>
<LINE>And very wisely threat before you sting.</LINE>
<LINE>Villains, you did not so, when your vile daggers</LINE>
<LINE>Hack'd one another in the sides of Caesar:</LINE>
You show'd your teeth like apes, and fawn'd like hounds,
<LINE>And bow'd like bondmen, kissing Caesar's feet;</LINE>
<LINE>Whilst damned Casca, like a cur, behind</LINE>
<LINE>Struck Caesar on the neck. O you flatterers!</LINE>
<LINE>This tongue had not offended so to-day,</LINE>
<LINE>Come, come, the cause: if arguing make us sweat,</LINE>
<LINE>The proof of it will turn to redder drops. Look;</LINE>
<LINE>When think you that the sword goes up again?</LINE>
<LINE>Never, till Caesar's three and thirty wounds</LINE>
<LINE>Be well avenged; or till another Caesar</LINE>
<LINE>Have added slaughter to the sword of traitors.</LINE>
<LINE>Caesar, thou canst not die by traitors' hands,</LINE>
<LINE>I was not born to die on Brutus' sword.</LINE>
<LINE>O, if thou wert the noblest of thy strain,</LINE>
<LINE>Young man, thou couldst not die more honourable.</LINE>
<LINE>A peevish schoolboy, worthless of such honour,</LINE>
<LINE>Join'd with a masker and a reveller!</LINE>
<LINE>Defiance, traitors, hurl we in your teeth:</LINE>
<LINE>If you dare fight to-day, come to the field;</LINE>
<LINE>Why, now, blow wind, swell billow and swim bark!</LINE>
<LINE>The storm is up, and all is on the hazard.</LINE>
<LINE>Ho, Lucilius! hark, a word with you.</LINE>
<LINE>This is my birth-day; as this very day</LINE>
<LINE>Was Cassius born. Give me thy hand, Messala:</LINE>
<LINE>Be thou my witness that against my will,</LINE>
<LINE>As Pompey was, am I compell'd to set</LINE>
<LINE>You know that I held Epicurus strong</LINE>
<LINE>And his opinion: now I change my mind,</LINE>
<LINE>And partly credit things that do presage.</LINE>
<LINE>Coming from Sardis, on our former ensign</LINE>
<LINE>Two mighty eagles fell, and there they perch'd,</LINE>
<LINE>Gorging and feeding from our soldiers' hands;</LINE>
<LINE>This morning are they fled away and gone;</LINE>
<LINE>And in their steads do ravens, crows and kites,</LINE>
<LINE>Fly o'er our heads and downward look on us,</LINE>
<LINE>As we were sickly prey: their shadows seem</LINE>
<LINE>Our army lies, ready to give up the ghost.</LINE>
<LINE>For I am fresh of spirit and resolved</LINE>
<LINE>The gods to-day stand friendly, that we may,</LINE>
<LINE>Lovers in peace, lead on our days to age!</LINE>
<LINE>But since the affairs of men rest still incertain,</LINE>
<LINE>Let's reason with the worst that may befall.</LINE>
<LINE>If we do lose this battle, then is this</LINE>
<LINE>The very last time we shall speak together:</LINE>
<LINE>What are you then determined to do?</LINE>
<LINE>Even by the rule of that philosophy</LINE>
<LINE>By which I did blame Cato for the death</LINE>
<LINE>Which he did give himself, I know not how,</LINE>
<LINE>But I do find it cowardly and vile,</LINE>
<LINE>For fear of what might fall, so to prevent</LINE>
<LINE>The time of life: arming myself with patience</LINE>
<LINE>To stay the providence of some high powers</LINE>
<LINE>You are contented to be led in triumph</LINE>
<LINE>No, Cassius, no: think not, thou noble Roman,</LINE>
<LINE>That ever Brutus will go bound to Rome;</LINE>
<LINE>He bears too great a mind. But this same day</LINE>
<LINE>Must end that work the ides of March begun;</LINE>
<LINE>And whether we shall meet again I know not.</LINE>
<LINE>For ever, and for ever, farewell, Cassius!</LINE>
<LINE>If we do meet again, why, we shall smile;</LINE>
<LINE>If not, why then, this parting was well made.</LINE>
<LINE>For ever, and for ever, farewell, Brutus!</LINE>
<LINE>If we do meet again, we'll smile indeed;</LINE>
<LINE>If not, 'tis true this parting was well made.</LINE>
<LINE>Why, then, lead on. O, that a man might know</LINE>
<LINE>The end of this day's business ere it come!</LINE>
<LINE>But it sufficeth that the day will end,</LINE>
<LINE>And then the end is known. Come, ho! away!</LINE>
<TITLE>SCENE II. The same. The field of battle.</TITLE>
<LINE>Ride, ride, Messala, ride, and give these bills</LINE>
<LINE>Unto the legions on the other side.</LINE>
<LINE>Let them set on at once; for I perceive</LINE>
<LINE>And sudden push gives them the overthrow.</LINE>
<LINE>Ride, ride, Messala: let them all come down.</LINE>
<TITLE>SCENE III. Another part of the field.</TITLE>
<LINE>O, look, Titinius, look, the villains fly!</LINE>
<LINE>Myself have to mine own turn'd enemy:</LINE>
<LINE>This ensign here of mine was turning back;</LINE>
<LINE>I slew the coward, and did take it from him.</LINE>
<LINE>O Cassius, Brutus gave the word too early;</LINE>
<LINE>Took it too eagerly: his soldiers fell to spoil,</LINE>
<LINE>Whilst we by Antony are all enclosed.</LINE>
<LINE>Fly further off, my lord, fly further off;</LINE>
<LINE>Mark Antony is in your tents, my lord</LINE>
<LINE>Fly, therefore, noble Cassius, fly far off.</LINE>
<LINE>This hill is far enough. Look, look, Titinius;</LINE>
<LINE>Are those my tents where I perceive the fire?</LINE>
<LINE>Mount thou my horse, and hide thy spurs in him,</LINE>
<LINE>Till he have brought thee up to yonder troops,</LINE>
<LINE>And here again; that I may rest assured</LINE>
<LINE>Whether yond troops are friend or enemy.</LINE>
<LINE>I will be here again, even with a thought.</LINE>
<LINE>Go, Pindarus, get higher on that hill;</LINE>
<LINE>My sight was ever thick; regard Titinius,</LINE>
<LINE>And tell me what thou notest about the field.</LINE>
<LINE>This day I breathed first: time is come round,</LINE>
<LINE>And where I did begin, there shall I end;</LINE>
<LINE>My life is run his compass. Sirrah, what news?</LINE>
<LINE>With horsemen, that make to him on the spur;</LINE>
<LINE>Yet he spurs on. Now they are almost on him.</LINE>
<LINE>Now, Titinius! Now some light. O, he lights too.</LINE>
<LINE>O, coward that I am, to live so long,</LINE>
<LINE>To see my best friend ta'en before my face!</LINE>
<LINE>In Parthia did I take thee prisoner;</LINE>
<LINE>And then I swore thee, saving of thy life,</LINE>
<LINE>That whatsoever I did bid thee do,</LINE>
Thou shouldst attempt it. Come now, keep thine oath;
<LINE>Now be a freeman: and with this good sword,</LINE>
That ran through Caesar's bowels, search this bosom.
<LINE>Stand not to answer: here, take thou the hilts;</LINE>
<LINE>And, when my face is cover'd, as 'tis now,</LINE>
<LINE>Even with the sword that kill'd thee.</LINE>
<LINE>So, I am free; yet would not so have been,</LINE>
<LINE>Durst I have done my will. O Cassius,</LINE>
<LINE>Far from this country Pindarus shall run,</LINE>
<LINE>Where never Roman shall take note of him.</LINE>
<LINE>It is but change, Titinius; for Octavius</LINE>
<LINE>With Pindarus his bondman, on this hill.</LINE>
<LINE>Is not that he that lies upon the ground?</LINE>
<LINE>He lies not like the living. O my heart!</LINE>
<LINE>But Cassius is no more. O setting sun,</LINE>
<LINE>As in thy red rays thou dost sink to-night,</LINE>
<LINE>So in his red blood Cassius' day is set;</LINE>
<LINE>The sun of Rome is set! Our day is gone;</LINE>
Clouds, dews, and dangers come; our deeds are done!
<LINE>Mistrust of my success hath done this deed.</LINE>
<LINE>Mistrust of good success hath done this deed.</LINE>
<LINE>Why dost thou show to the apt thoughts of men</LINE>
<LINE>The things that are not? O error, soon conceived,</LINE>
<LINE>Thou never comest unto a happy birth,</LINE>
<LINE>But kill'st the mother that engender'd thee!</LINE>
<LINE>Seek him, Titinius, whilst I go to meet</LINE>
<LINE>Into his ears; I may say, thrusting it;</LINE>
<LINE>Shall be as welcome to the ears of Brutus</LINE>
<LINE>And I will seek for Pindarus the while.</LINE>
<LINE>Why didst thou send me forth, brave Cassius?</LINE>
<LINE>Did I not meet thy friends? and did not they</LINE>
<LINE>Put on my brows this wreath of victory,</LINE>
And bid me give it thee? Didst thou not hear their shouts?
<LINE>But, hold thee, take this garland on thy brow;</LINE>
<LINE>Thy Brutus bid me give it thee, and I</LINE>
<LINE>Will do his bidding. Brutus, come apace,</LINE>
<LINE>And see how I regarded Caius Cassius.</LINE>
<LINE>By your leave, gods:--this is a Roman's part</LINE>
<LINE>Come, Cassius' sword, and find Titinius' heart.</LINE>
Alarum. Re-enter MESSALA, with BRUTUS, CATO, STRATO, VOLUMNIUS, and LUCILIUS
<LINE>Where, where, Messala, doth his body lie?</LINE>
<LINE>O Julius Caesar, thou art mighty yet!</LINE>
<LINE>Thy spirit walks abroad and turns our swords</LINE>
<LINE>Look, whether he have not crown'd dead Cassius!</LINE>
<LINE>Are yet two Romans living such as these?</LINE>
<LINE>The last of all the Romans, fare thee well!</LINE>
<LINE>Should breed thy fellow. Friends, I owe more tears</LINE>
<LINE>To this dead man than you shall see me pay.</LINE>
<LINE>I shall find time, Cassius, I shall find time.</LINE>
<LINE>Come, therefore, and to Thasos send his body:</LINE>
<LINE>His funerals shall not be in our camp,</LINE>
<LINE>And come, young Cato; let us to the field.</LINE>
<LINE>Labeo and Flavius, set our battles on:</LINE>
<LINE>'Tis three o'clock; and, Romans, yet ere night</LINE>
<LINE>We shall try fortune in a second fight.</LINE>
<TITLE>SCENE IV. Another part of the field.</TITLE>
Alarum. Enter fighting, Soldiers of both armies; then BRUTUS, CATO, LUCILIUS, and others
<LINE>Yet, countrymen, O, yet hold up your heads!</LINE>
<LINE>What bastard doth not? Who will go with me?</LINE>
<LINE>I will proclaim my name about the field:</LINE>
<LINE>I am the son of Marcus Cato, ho!</LINE>
<LINE>A foe to tyrants, and my country's friend;</LINE>
<LINE>I am the son of Marcus Cato, ho!</LINE>
<LINE>And I am Brutus, Marcus Brutus, I;</LINE>
<LINE>Brutus, my country's friend; know me for Brutus!</LINE>
<LINE>O young and noble Cato, art thou down?</LINE>
<LINE>Why, now thou diest as bravely as Titinius;</LINE>
<LINE>And mayst be honour'd, being Cato's son.</LINE>
<LINE>There is so much that thou wilt kill me straight;</LINE>
<LINE>Kill Brutus, and be honour'd in his death.</LINE>
<LINE>Room, ho! Tell Antony, Brutus is ta'en.</LINE>
<LINE>I'll tell the news. Here comes the general.</LINE>
<LINE>Brutus is ta'en, Brutus is ta'en, my lord.</LINE>
<LINE>I dare assure thee that no enemy</LINE>
<LINE>Shall ever take alive the noble Brutus:</LINE>
<LINE>The gods defend him from so great a shame!</LINE>
<LINE>When you do find him, or alive or dead,</LINE>
<LINE>He will be found like Brutus, like himself.</LINE>
<LINE>This is not Brutus, friend; but, I assure you,</LINE>
<LINE>A prize no less in worth: keep this man safe;</LINE>
<LINE>Give him all kindness: I had rather have</LINE>
<LINE>Such men my friends than enemies. Go on,</LINE>
<LINE>And see whether Brutus be alive or dead;</LINE>
<LINE>And bring us word unto Octavius' tent</LINE>
<TITLE>SCENE V. Another part of the field.</TITLE>
Enter BRUTUS, DARDANIUS, CLITUS, STRATO, and VOLUMNIUS
<LINE>Come, poor remains of friends, rest on this rock.</LINE>
<LINE>Statilius show'd the torch-light, but, my lord,</LINE>
<LINE>He came not back: he is or ta'en or slain.</LINE>
<LINE>Sit thee down, Clitus: slaying is the word;</LINE>
<LINE>It is a deed in fashion. Hark thee, Clitus.</LINE>
<LINE>What, I, my lord? No, not for all the world.</LINE>
<LINE>What ill request did Brutus make to thee?</LINE>
<LINE>To kill him, Clitus. Look, he meditates.</LINE>
<LINE>Now is that noble vessel full of grief,</LINE>
<LINE>That it runs over even at his eyes.</LINE>
<LINE>Come hither, good Volumnius; list a word.</LINE>
<LINE>The ghost of Caesar hath appear'd to me</LINE>
<LINE>Two several times by night; at Sardis once,</LINE>
<LINE>And, this last night, here in Philippi fields:</LINE>
<LINE>Nay, I am sure it is, Volumnius.</LINE>
<LINE>Thou seest the world, Volumnius, how it goes;</LINE>
<LINE>Our enemies have beat us to the pit:</LINE>
<LINE>It is more worthy to leap in ourselves,</LINE>
<LINE>Than tarry till they push us. Good Volumnius,</LINE>
<LINE>Thou know'st that we two went to school together:</LINE>
<LINE>Even for that our love of old, I prithee,</LINE>
<LINE>Hold thou my sword-hilts, whilst I run on it.</LINE>
<LINE>That's not an office for a friend, my lord.</LINE>
<LINE>Fly, fly, my lord; there is no tarrying here.</LINE>
<LINE>Farewell to you; and you; and you, Volumnius.</LINE>
<LINE>Strato, thou hast been all this while asleep;</LINE>
<LINE>My heart doth joy that yet in all my life</LINE>
<LINE>I found no man but he was true to me.</LINE>
<LINE>I shall have glory by this losing day</LINE>
<LINE>By this vile conquest shall attain unto.</LINE>
<LINE>So fare you well at once; for Brutus' tongue</LINE>
<LINE>Night hangs upon mine eyes; my bones would rest,</LINE>
<LINE>That have but labour'd to attain this hour.</LINE>
<LINE>I prithee, Strato, stay thou by thy lord:</LINE>
<LINE>Thou art a fellow of a good respect;</LINE>
<LINE>Thy life hath had some smatch of honour in it:</LINE>
<LINE>Hold then my sword, and turn away thy face,</LINE>
<LINE>While I do run upon it. Wilt thou, Strato?</LINE>
<LINE>Give me your hand first. Fare you well, my lord.</LINE>
<LINE>I kill'd not thee with half so good a will.</LINE>
Alarum. Retreat. Enter OCTAVIUS, ANTONY, MESSALA, LUCILIUS, and the army
<LINE>My master's man. Strato, where is thy master?</LINE>
<LINE>Free from the bondage you are in, Messala:</LINE>
<LINE>The conquerors can but make a fire of him;</LINE>
<LINE>And no man else hath honour by his death.</LINE>
<LINE>So Brutus should be found. I thank thee, Brutus,</LINE>
<LINE>That thou hast proved Lucilius' saying true.</LINE>
<LINE>All that served Brutus, I will entertain them.</LINE>
<LINE>Fellow, wilt thou bestow thy time with me?</LINE>
<LINE>Ay, if Messala will prefer me to you.</LINE>
<LINE>I held the sword, and he did run on it.</LINE>
<LINE>Octavius, then take him to follow thee,</LINE>
<LINE>That did the latest service to my master.</LINE>
<LINE>This was the noblest Roman of them all:</LINE>
<LINE>Did that they did in envy of great Caesar;</LINE>
<LINE>He only, in a general honest thought</LINE>
<LINE>And common good to all, made one of them.</LINE>
<LINE>His life was gentle, and the elements</LINE>
<LINE>So mix'd in him that Nature might stand up</LINE>
<LINE>And say to all the world 'This was a man!'</LINE>
<LINE>According to his virtue let us use him,</LINE>
<LINE>With all respect and rites of burial.</LINE>
<LINE>Within my tent his bones to-night shall lie,</LINE>
<LINE>So call the field to rest; and let's away,</LINE>
<LINE>To part the glories of this happy day.</LINE>
